newsitem.title: UK: UK pension group warns against corporate tax rise.
newsitem.headline: UK pension group warns against corporate tax rise.

text.p: The National Association of Pension Funds (NAPF) on Thursday warned Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown against cutting into tax advantages granted to pension funds.

Speaking at the association's annual conference at Harrogate, NAPF director general Ann Robinson expressed "deep concern" at the spectre of the abolition of Advanced Corporation Tax (ACT), a tax break enjoyed by pension funds and other tax-exempt dividend recipients.
"This would be ill-advised - a serious mistake," Robinson said.
The NAPF is worried that Labour pledges not to raise individual income tax would leave it little choice but to look to corporations to fill the gap.
Pension funds are currently given a 20 percent tax credit on dividends, a policy that the NAPF supports on the grounds that tax is eventually paid on pension income received by individuals.
"Imposing a tax on dividends to pension funds has the effect of imposing double taxation on individuals" Robinson said.
ACT is levied from a company's gross profits at the same time as dividends are paid to shareholders.
It can be offset against a company's corporation tax liability, which means that it does not increase a company's overall tax burden.

Tax-exempt organisations, such as pension funds, benefit from a higher rate of ACT because they can claim more cash back from the government, so they would bear the financial brunt of any government plan to drop the rate.

If ACT was abolished, the NAPF believes that profitable corporations would have to divert funds to their own pension funds to make up any shortfall - thus reducing corporation tax revenue to the government.
Also, reductions in pension fund revenues among local authorities and other public service sector pension funds could result in "higher taxes or reduced services to the public", Robinson said.
The NAPF believes that a cut in ACT would also make more difficult the government's plans for so-called stakeholder pensions.
"You simply won't get stakeholder pensions if you tax, tax, tax," Robinson said.
